Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with pZeoSV2 full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 constructs.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 showed significantly reduced stabilities compared to WT protein.
L166P DJ-1 showed significantly reduced stabilities compared to WT protein.
P158DEL DJ-1 showed significantly reduced stabilities compared to WT protein.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Basic positive control.Description: CHO cells were transfected with full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL human DJ-1 pZeoSV2 (+) constructs.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Experiment Method.Assay Method: Co-Immunoprecipitation and Heterodimer or Homodimer Analysis

Material used.Description: CHO cells were co-transfected with HA-tagged full-length WT DJ-1 and pZeoSV2 (+) mock vector (mock) or with untagged full-length WT, L10P, P158DEL, or L166P human DJ-1 pZeoSV2 (+) constructs. At 24 hours post transfection, cells were harvested and soluble protein lysates were extracted (Start). The cell lysates were then immunoprecipitated using anti-HA polyclonal antibody (IP).

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 retained the ability to dimerize with WT DJ-1 protein but was unable to form homodimers.
P158DEL DJ-1 retained the ability to dimerize with WT DJ-1 protein but was unable to form homodimers.
L166P DJ-1 was unable to dimerize with WT DJ-1 protein and also unable to form homodimers.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Mock transfection was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with pZeoSV2 full-length untagged WT, L10P, P158DEL, or L166P human DJ-1 constructs. At 48 hours post transfection, cells were lysed in PBS/0.1% Triton. DSS was added at various concentrations and proteins were cross-linked for 2 hrs at 4 °C.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 was deficient in the ability to form homodimers under the experimental conditions.
L166P DJ-1 was deficient in the ability to form homodimers under the experimental conditions.
P158DEL DJ-1 was deficient in the ability to form homodimers under the experimental conditions.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Mock transfection was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Material used.Description: CHO cells transiently expressing human full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL DJ-1 were cultured in 100 mm dishes, grown to confluency, and harvested. Soluble extracts were loaded onto a precalibrated Superose 6 column.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 exhibited an elution profile consistent with a slightly larger conformation than WT protein, suggesting altered protein folding.
P158DEL DJ-1 exhibited an elution profile indicating that it is natively smaller in size than WT protein, suggesting altered protein folding and possibly predominantly monomeric.
L166P DJ-1 eluted in a peak fraction earlier than WT DJ-1, suggesting it forms high-molecular weight complexes, indicative of altered protein folding.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Mock transfection was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Experiment Method.Assay Method: Biochemical Fractionation and Cell Compartment Fractionation

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with pZeoSV2 full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL DJ-1 constructs. At 24 hours post transfection, cells were cultured for an additional 18 hours in fresh DMEM with or without the addition of either 20 µM MG-132 or 1 µM epoxomicin. Cells were harvested and sequentially extracted into PBS/0.1% Triton (TX) buffer, RIPA buffer, and 2% SDS/17mM Tris (SDS) buffer.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 showed reduced solubility compared to WT protein, with a significant fraction extracted in the RIPA and SDS fractions. Proteasome inhibition dramatically promoted the accumulation of RIPA and SDS-soluble forms of L10P DJ-1.

L166P DJ-1 showed reduced solubility compared to WT protein, with a significant fraction extracted in the RIPA and SDS fractions. Proteasome inhibition resulted in the build-up of Triton-insoluble pools of L166P DJ-1.

P158DEL DJ-1 showed reduced solubility compared to WT protein, with a significant fraction extracted in the RIPA and SDS fractions. Proteasome inhibition did not significantly affect the biochemical extractability of P158DEL DJ-1 protein.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Mock transfection was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Material used.Description: CHO cells were transfected with pZeoSV2 full-length WT, L10P, L166P, or P158DEL DJ-1 constructs. At 48 hours post transfection, cells were cultured for an additional 12 hours in fresh DMEM with or without the addition of 20 µM MG-132. Cells were rinsed in PBS and fixed by incubation in ice-cold acetic-methanol.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 showed increased inclusion formation following proteasome inhibition. Approximately 84±13% of cells expressing L10P DJ-1 had inclusions after treatment with MG-132.
L166P DJ-1 showed increased inclusion formation following proteasome inhibition. 49±10% of cells expressing L166P DJ-1 had inclusions after treatment with MG-132.
P158DEL DJ-1 showed increased inclusion formation following proteasome inhibition. 68±11% of cells expressing P158DEL DJ-1 had inclusions after treatment with MG-132.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.

Material used.Description: CHO cells stably expressing WT or L10P DJ-1 were generated and treated with 25 µM MG-132, 50 µM MG-132, or 1 µM epoxomicin for 21 hours.

Readout description.Result Description: L10P DJ-1 showed significantly reduced viability compared to native CHO cells after treatment with 25 µM and 50 µM MG-132, and higher expression of mutant DJ-1 protein correlated with increased toxicity during proteasome stress.
N.D.
N.D.

Biological replicates.Description: The experiment was conducted in triplicates.

Technical replicates.Description: Each sample was run in triplicate.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ-1 was used as a positive control, showing protection against proteasome inhibitors.

Basic negative control.Description: Native CHO cells were used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Two-way ANOVA and Bonferroni’s post hoc test.
